xxl.core.indexStructures

Class BPlusTree.QueryCursor

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor
      • xxl.core.indexStructures.QueryCursor
        • xxl.core.indexStructures.BPlusTree.QueryCursor
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterator, Cursor
    Enclosing class:
    BPlusTree

    protected class BPlusTree.QueryCursor
extends QueryCursor
    This class uses an efficient algorithm to perform queries on the BPlusTree. It does not traverse the BPlusTree in TOP-DOWN fashion to find the response set, but it uses the known efficient querying algorithm of B+-Tree. It only traverses the path to the first Node, which can contain answers, and then traverses the Nodes on the same level cross the BPlusTree from left to right, using the nextNeighbor references of BPlusTree.Node.

    • Field Detail

      • index

        protected int index
        The position of the current entry in the current Node.

      • lastIndex

        protected int lastIndex
        The position of the last entry in the last Node.

      • lastIndexEntry

        protected BPlusTree.IndexEntry lastIndexEntry
        The IndexEntry of the last Node.

      • lastNode

        protected BPlusTree.Node lastNode
        The last Node, i.e. the Node which contains the last entry returned by the QueryCursor. It is used as a history information to support remove an update.

      • nodeChangeover

        protected int nodeChangeover
        A counter which counts how many Nodes on the target level was already visited. The number of the visited Nodes equals nodeChangeover+1.

      • prevSeparator

        protected Separator prevSeparator
        The previous Separator of the lastIndexEntry. Needed to support the remove-operation.

      • counterRightShiftDup

        protected int counterRightShiftDup
        counts occurrence of the elements with the same separator key in the cursor

        Creates a new QueryCursor.
        Parameters:
        subRootEntry - the IndexEntry which is the root of the subtree in which the query has to be executed
        qInterval - a Descriptor which specifies the query
        targetLevel - the target level of the query

    • Method Detail

      • hasNextObject

        public boolean hasNextObject()
        Checks whether a next element exists. First builds the path down to the target level, using only the left element from the Iterator returned by BPlusTree.Node.query(Descriptor) Method searches through target level from left to right within the query range, looking through each node in turn. At the end of each node it switches to the next node using nodeChangeover, It searches until it has found an item right of min bound then tests this item if it is left from max bound and returns this boolean.
        Specified by:
        hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor
        Returns:
        true if there is a next element and false otherwise
        See Also:
        AbstractCursor.hasNextObject();

      • nextObject

        public Object nextObject()
        Computes the next element of the QueryCursor.
        Specified by:
        nextObject in class AbstractCursor
        Returns:
        the next element

      • removeObject

        protected void removeObject()
        Removes the last element returned by the method next() and calls the method BPlusTree.treatUnderflow(Stack)to repair underflows which can occur. It is only supported on the level 0. If the path is not correct (due to nodeChangover) then it will be calculated. The root descriptor is updated if the min or max object is deleted.
        Specified by:
        removeObject in class QueryCursor

      • backToFirstEntry

        protected void backToFirstEntry(Stack path,
                                Separator prevSep,
                                boolean computeIndex)
        Searches for the left most element that has the same key as the deleted item, constructs the path in queryCursor.
        Parameters:
        path -
        prevSep -

      • updateObject

        protected void updateObject(Object newData)
        Replaces the last element returned by the method next() by a new data object. It is only supported on the level 0.
        Specified by:
        updateObject in class QueryCursor
        Parameters:
        newData - the new data object

      • supportsReset

        public boolean supportsReset()
        Description copied from class: AbstractCursor
        Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the cursor. Otherwise it returns false.

        The current implementation of this method is as follows: 

           public boolean supportsReset() {
       return false;
   }

        Specified by:
        supportsReset in interface Cursor
        Overrides:
        supportsReset in class AbstractCursor
        Returns:
        true if the reset operation is supported by the cursor, otherwise false.
        See Also:
        Cursor.supportsReset()

      • reset

        public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
        Description copied from class: AbstractCursor
        Resets the cursor to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the underlying data structure again without constructing a new cursor (optional operation). The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying data structure, are still persistent.

        Note, that this operation is optional and does not work for this cursor.

        The current implementation of this method is as follows: 

           public void reset() throws IllegalStateException,
                              UnsupportedOperationException {
       if (!supportsReset())
           throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
       hasNext = false;
       computedHasNext = false;
       isValid = false;
       assignedNext = false;
   }

        Specified by:
        reset in interface Cursor
        Overrides:
        reset in class AbstractCursor
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the cursor.
        See Also:
        Cursor.reset()
